opening: Lord, meet us gently today and always
body:
I read this passage and I realize how exposed I feel.
James says that trials produce perseverance.
He says to consider them joy.
But if I’m honest, what I feel isn’t joy.
It feels heavy.
It feels unfair.
It feels like loss.
I’m in deep waters right now.
I don’t have a job.
There is no steady income.
There is a mortgage.
There is college ahead for my children.
There is the quiet pressure of needing to retire someday.
I don’t see how any of this becomes good.
I know faith is not the same as sight.
I know believing often means trusting without evidence.
But I also know that I am sad.
And I don’t want to pretend I’m joyful when I’m not.
Maybe “consider it joy” doesn’t mean feel happy.
Maybe it means choosing not to walk away.
Choosing not to harden.
Choosing to stay in conversation with God even when my prayers sound more like questions than praise.
So today, my faith looks small.
It looks like showing up.
It looks like saying, “Lord, I don’t understand, but I’m still here.”
And maybe that, too, is perseverance being formed.
Not in fireworks.
Not in certainty.
But in quiet endurance.
God, meet me here. I love and praise your name.  

The Gospel: 

“They sought from Him a sign from heaven to test Him.”

I recognize myself in that line.

Not in rebellion.
Not in defiance.
But in exhaustion.

Because when life becomes heavy, the heart quietly starts asking:

God, can You just show me something?
Can You give me proof that You are still working?
Can You give me a sign that this is going somewhere?

I don’t think I’m trying to trap God.
I think I’m trying to survive.

When Jesus is asked for a sign, He does not perform on demand.
He doesn’t turn God into a spectacle.
He doesn’t bend heaven to soothe anxiety in the moment.

Instead, He keeps revealing the same truth in quieter ways:
through His presence,
through His mercy,
through His willingness to remain with people in their need.

In my own season, I realize I’ve been asking for a sign that everything will be okay.
A sign that the job will come.
A sign that finances will stabilize.
A sign that the pressure will lift.

But maybe the deeper sign is this:

I’m still praying.
I’m still turning toward Him.
I’m still bringing my fear into His presence instead of running from Him.

That is not nothing.

Maybe faith isn’t built by dramatic proof.
Maybe it’s built by staying.

Staying when I don’t understand.
Staying when I don’t see outcomes.
Staying when hope feels thin.

Jesus does not shame those who are tired.
He invites them to something stronger than signs: trust.

Not trust because circumstances look good.
Not trust because answers arrived.
But trust because God’s character has not changed.

So today, I’m learning to pray differently.

Not: “God, prove Yourself.”
But: “God, hold me while I don’t see.”

And maybe that, too, is a holy kind of faith.
